repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Public Sector Adjustment
            Loan/Credit Project (PSAL), Structural Adjustment Loan
            Project (SAL), and the First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit (SAC I and SAC II) Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the four projects are as
            follows: PSAL's outcome is rated moderately
            unsatisfactory; Improvements in loan repayment have been
            sustained and are likely to continue. Subsequent debt
            rescheduling and improvements in macro management have also
            reduced the threat of default. Even though debt service
            levels remain high, sustainability of these net benefits is
            rated likely. Institutional development is negligible.
            Overall, both Bank and Borrower performance are rated
            unsatisfactory.  SAL's outcome is rated as moderately
            unsatisfactory. Improvements in loan repayment have been
            sustained and are likely to continue. Even though debt
            service levels remain high, sustainability of these net
            benefits is rated likely. Institutional reform was
            negligible. Because of the failure to implement the reform
            program, Borrower performance is rated unsatisfactory. The
            problems with SAL reflect a lack of broad-based commitment
            in Pakistan, not the program design; Bank performance is
            rated satisfactory.  Overall, outcome of SAC I is rated
            satisfactory, and sustainability of project achievements is
            likely. Overall institutional development impact is rated
            modest. Performance o f both the Bank and the Borrower are
            rated satisfactory. The overall outcome of SAC II is rated
            as moderately satisfactory, and sustainability of net
            project benefits is rated likely. SAC II had important
            institutional objectives in tax administration, public
            financial management, civil service reform, procurement, and
            utility restructuring and regulation. Overall institutional
            development impact is rated modest. Both Bank and Borrower
            performance are rated satisfactory.  The main lessons from
            these loans are: 1) Effectiveness of a series of one-tranche
            loans depends on a willingness to withhold lending until a
            critical mass of previously-agreed prior actions have been
            undertaken. The delay between the SAL and the first SAC was
            particularly effective in this respect.2) Complex or
            politically difficult sector reforms are best supported
            through dedicated sector operations. A multi-sector
            operation can play only a secondary or facilitating role
            when dealing with institutional development (as in tax
            reform or civil service reform), deep-rooted reluctance to
            reform (as in power), need for specific funding to offset
            costs of adjustment (as in banking), or weak service
            delivery (as in health and education).

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Public Sector Adjustment
            Loan/Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Public Sector
            Adjustment Loan/Credit Project for Pakistan was marginally
            satisfactory. The project achieved some of its objectives,
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            uncertain, and the performance of the Bank was marginally
            satisfactory while the Borrower's was satisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First,
            lessons of experience from previous adjustment operations
            need to be built into the design of succeeding operations.
            Second, care must be taken by the Bank to avoid sending
            unclear or mixed messages to a Government regarding the
            prerequisites of adjustment lending. Third, it may take
            years to prepare adequately to seize a moment. Fourth,
            covenants should be concentrated only on measures which the
            Bank has existing in-depth knowledge. Fifth, adjustment
            operations can be designed with a "process
            approach". Sixth, the design of reform programs should
            be replete with ID measures to strengthen both near-term and
            long-term implementation capacity. Seventh, supervision
            should be forward looking and focused not so much upon
            details of compliance and actions taken as upon problem
            solving and implementation assistance. Finally, governance
            is generally crucial to sustainability.

repnme.cdata!: Pakistan - Public Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The government of Pakistan has been
            implementing macroeconomic and structural reform since the
            mid 1980s. This loan will support Government efforts to
            address public finance issues; deregulate the economy and
            redefine the role of the public sector; and improve private
            sector productivity. The improvements in resource
            mobilization and in current and development expenditures
            will contribute to better budget management and fiscal
            stability. In addition, the support for improved planning
            and prioritization of investments as well as adequate
            funding for current expenditures will make the policies more
            effective. The adjustment program encompasses macroeconomic,
            privatization, public finance, and trade policy reforms.
